Fig. 1 Transmission electron microscopic images obtained for (a,b) undoped GONR and (c-d) N-GONR samples. (e) XPS survey spectra. HR-XPS spectra in the O 1s region for (f) undoped GONR and (g) N-GONR. (h) HR-XPS spectra in the N 1s region for N-GONR sample. (i) Raman and (j) FT-IR (KBr pellet) spectra obtained for the undoped GONR and N-GONR samples. Fig. 2 Linear sweep voltammetry in a RRDE configuration, with scanning at the potential of 5 mV s−1 and 900 rpm in O2-sat 0.1 mol L−1 HClO4 (scans started at −0.3 VRHE) or O2-sat 0.1 mol L−1 KOH (scans started at 0.0 VRHE) for GC modified electrode with 200 µg cm−2 of fresh undoped GONR or N-GONR: (a,d) disk current densities. (b,e) Ring currents. (c,f) S H 2 O 2 during ORR at varying potentials (obtained from the corresponding RRDE data). Fig. 3 Linear sweep voltammetry in a RRDE configuration, with scanning at the potential of 5 mV s−1 and 900 rpm in O2-sat 0.1 mol L−1 HClO4 (scans started at −0.3 VRHE) or O2-sat 0.1 mol L−1 KOH (scans started at 0.0 VRHE) for GC modified electrode with 200 µg cm−2 of undoped GONR or N-GONR before and after the conduct of chronoamperometric experiments: (a,d) disk current densities. (b,e) Ring currents. (c,f) S H 2 O 2 during ORR at varying potentials (obtained from the corresponding RRDE data). Fig. 4 (a,c) Average selectivity toward H2O2( S H 2 O 2 ) before and after chronoamperometric experiments for the N-GONR and undoped GONR (values obtained from the corresponding RRDE data). Cyclic voltammograms obtained from the application of GC electrode modified with 200 µg cm−2 of N-GONR or undoped GONR in (b) N2-sat 0.1 M HClO4 (scan rate: 50 mV s−1; scans started at 1.3 VRHE) and in (d) N2-sat 0.1 M KOH (scan rate: 50 mV s−1; scans started at 1.1 VRHE) solutions before and after the conduct of chronoamperometric experiments. Fig. 5 (a) Ionic currents for CO2 (m/z = 44), O2 (m/z = 32), and (b) faradaic currents obtained during DEMS-based chronoamperometric experiments for Au disk electrode modified with 200 µg cm−2 of N-GONR, undoped GONR or Vulcan carbon applied in O2-sat 0.1 mol L−1 HClO4. Fig. 6 (a) N/C and O/C atomic ratios for the N-GONR or undoped GONR before and after the conduct of chronoamperometric experiments (values obtained from XPS quantification, Table S2). (b) HR-XPS spectra in the C 1s region for N-GONR before and after the conduct of chronoamperometric experiments. (c) Content of nitrogen groups in the N-GONR and undoped GONR samples before and after the conduct of chronoamperometric experiments (values obtained from the deconvolution data for XPS curves shown in Fig. S3 and Table S3). Fig. 7 FT-IR (KBr pellet) and Raman spectra for (a,c) N-GONR and (b,d) undoped GONR before and after the conduct of chronoamperometric experiments. Fig. 8 HR-TEM representative images of the N-GONR and undoped GONR samples after the conduct of chronoamperometric experiments. The scale bars are 10 nm. Graphical abstract Carbon materials have widespread use in catalysis mainly due to their abundance, high conductivity, large surface area, and facile functionalization through heteroatom-doping. However, both, the stability against corrosion and the catalytic performance caused by the exposure to high potentials present in relevant electrocatalytic reactions such as the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is recurrently underestimated. We demonstrate that importance of oxygen and nitrogen binding motives to tailor the oxygen reduction activity, selectivity and stability against corrosion. Spectroscopic results revealed that the exposure to high oxidative potentials causes i) oxidation of N-groups and decrease in N content; and ii) enrichment of CO (hydroxyl and ethers), CO (quinones), and COOH functional groups and, together, dramatically impact the ORR activity and selectivity. We present guidelines how the activity, selectivity and stability can be precisely tuned. The developed guidelines highlight the potential of tailoring the oxygen and nitrogen containing functional groups on carbon catalysts for future catalytic applications. Keywords Graphene oxide nanoribbons Nitrogen-doping Functional groups Carbon corrosion Electrochemical stability Peroxide production Oxygen reduction reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon materials have been a long success story in catalysis due to their abundance, chemical inertness, high conductivity, and facile tractability in terms of structure, pore volume, pore size, morphology and composition [1–5]. Its abundance and low price render it a sustainable alternative to metal-based catalysts and carbonaceous materials have gained great attention in relevant electrocatalytic reactions such as the oxygen reduction reaction. The ORR is considered one of the most important reactions due to its association with energy conversion (fuel cell) and storage (metal-air batteries) processes and the electrocatalytic production of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) [6–9]. Especially in ORR electrocatalysis, it is known that the structure, nature, and doping of carbon materials with suitable heteroatoms can strongly impact the performance of the catalyst [10]. For instance, the functionalization of carbon with nitrogen or oxygen affects the ORR mechanism in favor of generating water or H2O2 as the main product [6,11–16]. Similarly to activity and selectivity, the stability of the catalyst material is of upper importance for catalytic performance [17,18]. Although carbonaceous materials are expected to be chemically inert in several catalytic systems, carbon is known to be prone to (electrochemical) oxidation when subjected to high potentials. Even though carbon corrosion can be thermodynamically expected at low potentials (E C/CO2 = 0.21 VSHE; E C/CO = 0.52 VSHE), in reality, this occurs at potentials over 1.4 VRHE. In fuel cells, these potentials might be observed during the start-stop and shut-down processes [19–24]. Carbon oxidation is expected to drastically affect the performance and lifetime of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) mainly due to particle detachment, decrease of hydrophobicity, and the loss of porosity [22,25–28]. As carbon properties such as porosity, degree of graphitization, and heteroatom-doping ability may affect the catalytic performance in ORR, they are also expected to affect carbon’s nobility and resistance to oxidation [29–35]. Although great advances have been made in terms of increasing the catalytic activity during the ORR, both, the resistance against corrosion and the electrocatalytic stability of carbonaceous materials remains unsettled. Furthermore, to the best of our knowledge, to date, there have not been any qualitative or quantitative reports on the impact of carbon oxidation on ORR activity and selectivity. In order to shed light on this particular issue, we doped hydrothermally synthesized graphene oxide nanoribbons (GONR) with nitrogen as a model carbon catalyst and evaluated the ORR activity, selectivity, and electrochemical stability of the catalyst prior to and after applying different oxidative potentials in both acidic and alkaline media. To evaluate the stability of the synthesized material, differential electrochemical mass spectroscopy (DEMS) was used for the on-line detection of CO2 from carbon oxidation. Changes in the catalyst surface chemistry were monitored by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Fourier Transform Infrared and Raman spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy; the effects of the changes in the catalyst surface chemistry on ORR activity were investigated using the rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) analytical technique. Together, our results demonstrate that N-doping/O-doping increases the stability of earth abundant carbon materials for catalytic applications, as well as altering the oxygen and nitrogen ratios by exposing carbon catalysts to oxidative potentials enables to tailor the ORR activity, selectivity and stability. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals The chemical compounds used for the conduct of the experiments included the following: potassium persulfate (K2S2O8, 99 % purity), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30 %), sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 98 %), phosphorus pentoxide (P2O5, 99 %) and ammonia hydroxide (NH4OH) solution (28 wt% in H2O) - all were acquired from Vetec (Duque de Caxias, RJ, Brazil). Analytical grade sodium nitrate (NaNO3), hydrochloric acid (HCl), potassium hydroxide (KOH) and perchloric acid (HClO4) were obtained from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany); potassium permanganate (KMnO4, 98 %) and hydrazine sulfate (NH2NH2.H2SO4, 99 %) were acquired from Nuclear (Diadema, SP, Brazil). Multiwalled carbon nanotubes (≥98 % purity, containing 6–8 tube walls) were purchased from Aldrich (Saint Louis, MO, USA). All solutions were prepared using ultrapure water obtained from a Milli-Q equipment with resistivity higher than 18 MΩ cm and temperature of 25 °C. 2.2 Synthesis of undoped and N-doped GONR The synthesis of GONR using multi-walled carbon nanotubes has been described elsewhere [36]. The doping of GONR with nitrogen was performed based on the synthesis method reported by Cardoso et al. with some adaptations [37]. Briefly, 60 mg of GONR were dispersed in 60 mL ultrapure water in an ultrasonic bath for at least 60 min. Thereafter, 3 mL of NH4OH solution (28 wt%) and 3.18 g of NH2NH2.H2SO4 were added, and the mixture was kept at 95 °C under magnetic stirring for 3 h. Afterwards, the precipitate was cleaned by centrifugation with ultrapure water at least three times. In the second step, the product was mixed with 60 mL of NH4OH and kept for 12 h in an autoclave at 150 °C. Finally, the product obtained (N-GONR) was cleaned by centrifugation at 9000 rpm (using a Hettich Universal 320 centrifuge) several times with ultrapure water and was then dried overnight at 50 ℃ in an oven. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements Rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) measurements were carried out in a three-electrode glass cell with the following specifications: Teflon-embedded glassy carbon-disk/Pt-ring (geometric areas: disk = 0.247 cm2 and ring = 0.186 cm2 - acquired from Pine Research Instrumentation) was used as working electrode, a graphite rod was employed as counter-electrode, and a saturated Ag/AgCl electrode (∼3.0 M KCl, Analyser Co.) was used as reference electrode. To obtain a uniform microlayer with a catalyst loading of 200 μg cm−2, an amount of 20 µL of catalyst solution (2.5 mg mL−1 in dimethylformamide – acquired from Aldrich) was drop casted onto clean glassy carbon (GC) disk electrode and dried under N2-flux. All potentials showed in the electrochemical results are plotted in relation to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). For the potential conversion, prior to every measurement, the RHE potential vs an Ag/AgCl reference electrode was measured in the corresponding electrolyte after H2 saturation on the Pt-ring electrode. Cyclic voltammetry (CV), linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and chronoamperometry (CA) measurements were conducted using a Metrohm Autolab model PGSTAT-128 N potentiostat/galvanostat connected to an AFMSRX rotator with MSRX speed controller (Pine Research, USA). For the ORR analysis in acidic medium, to detect the H2O2 generated, the Pt ring electrode was kept at 1.3 V vs RHE in O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 solution while the potentials on the modified GC disks were scanned in the same solution at the potential window of −0.30 to 1.0 V vs RHE. In alkaline medium, the measurements were performed keeping the Pt ring electrode at 1.3 V vs RHE in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution while the potentials on the modified GC disks were scanned at the potential window of 0 to 1.0 V vs RHE. All the LSV measurements were performed at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 starting at the lowest potential. ORR curves were obtained by subtracting background currents to eliminate any current contributions from the electrodes in contact with the electrolyte. The RRDE data and Eq. (1) and (2) were used to calculate the selectivity toward H2O2 production (SH2O2) and the number of electrons transferred per O2 molecule (n) during the ORR [38,39]: (1) S H 2 O 2 = 2 I r N I d + I r N × 100 % (2) n = 4 I d I d + I r N where I d is the disk current, I r the ring current, and N is the collection efficiency (0.37). In order to evaluate the catalyst stability at oxidative potential, electrochemical surface oxidations of the catalysts were performed by chronoamperometry (CA). The CA measurements were performed based on the application of the potentials 1.5, 1.7, and 1.9 V vs RHE for acidic medium (0.1 M HClO4), and 1.5 and 1.7 V vs RHE for alkaline medium (0.1 M KOH) for 5 or 30 min. For the CA measurements in alkaline medium, the upper potential (1.7 V vs RHE) was chosen due to the high physical stability of the catalyst films. The CO2 (mass/charge (m/z) ionic signal selected was 44) formed during the chronoamperometric assays was monitored via on-line DEMS measurements. In a typical DEMS experiment, the volatile and gaseous products formed on the surface of the working electrode are instantaneously detected by the mass spectrometer. The results are reported as mass intensities vs time for each m/z value of the ionic current signal, in parallel with the current vs time and current vs potential. The system is formed by a three-neck round bottom electrochemical cell with the working electrode located at the interface between the DEMS equipment (OmniStarTM GSD 320 Gas Analyzer from Pfeiffer Vacuum) and the electrochemical cell [40]. The working electrode/interface was prepared using a disk-shaped gold foil (99.99 % trace metals basis - Sigma-Aldrich). Small holes were made manually in the gold foil using a hypodermic needle to allow gas diffusion through the working electrode/interface. The perforated foil was then pressed against a PTFE membrane (Gore-Tex®, 0.02 µm of pore size and 50 µm of thickness) in a holder. The catalyst solution (80 µL of catalyst solution – 2.5 mg mL−1 in dimethylformamide - from Aldrich) was drop casted on the gold foil electrode and dried under N2-flux. The PTFE/gold plate/catalyst disk was placed inside a homemade holder (PEEK®), and 3 PTFE membrane disks (10 mm diameter) and a stainless-steel frit were then positioned over the electrode [40]. The system was screwed to a stainless-steel tube connected to the DEMS equipment. The area of the working electrode exposed to the bulk of the solution was 0.38 cm2. The electrical contact is made by a titanium wire pressed against the non-exposed area of the working electrode and carefully isolated from the electrolyte with a PTFE tape. 2.4 Material characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analyses were performed using a FEI TECNAI G2 F20 HRTEM microscope (accelerating voltage: 200 kV). Supported on lacey carbon film on copper grids (Electron Microscopy Sciences), TEM samples were elaborated from diluted catalyst inks prepared using the films collected from the electrode surface. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were carried out using Scienta Omicron ESCA + spectrometer. The operation conditions were as follows: X-ray source of Al Kα (1486.7 eV); pass energies of 50 (for survey) and 10 eV (for high-resolution spectra); and excitation source of 20 kV at 25 W. Carbon paper HCP030N was used as working electrode and catalyst support to produce the XPS samples. Through the application of the Casa XPS® software, high-resolution (HR) XPS spectra were deconvoluted according to the information found in the literature [11,41,42] using the Voigt-type function with Gaussian and Lorentzian (70 %/30 %) combinations after the background subtraction (Shirley method). The room temperature (25 °C) Raman spectra were obtained from a LabRam HR Evolution micro-Raman spectrometer (Horiba Jobin-Yvon), using a solid-state laser operating at 633 nm, a standard grating (600gr/mm) and an EMCCD detector (Synapse EM). The samples were excited with low laser intensity (∼2 mW) to avoid overheating and the occurrence of photochemical phenomena. A 100 × objective (Olympus, MPlan N) was used to focus the laser on the sample. The spectra were collected in an acquisition time of 12 s. The Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were obtained using a Bomen Fourier transform infrared spectrophotometer at the spectral window ranging from 400 to 4000 cm−1. The catalyst samples were prepared from the dried material collected from the electrode surface (∼30 µg) together with KBr (35 mg), which was ground using a mortar until a fine and homogeneous powder was obtained. The powder was then pressed to form a translucent tablet. CNHS-O elemental analyses (EA) were carried out using a Thermo Scientific FlashSmart CNHS-O elemental analyzer. The EA samples were analyzed under the following operating conditions: i) for CHNS determinations: cycle (run time) of 720 s with oven temperature of 950 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material characterization To determine the effect of heteroatom doping, we hydrothermally synthesized graphene oxide nanoribbons (GONR) doped with nitrogen. The undoped GONR and N-GONR were characterized by TEM to ascertain morphological differences and similarities. The micrographs (Fig. 1 a-d) of both catalyst samples exhibited similar morphologies with stacked unzipped carbon structures. Microscopically, no changes were found to occur in the nanoribbon structure before and after the doping of GONR with N [43,44]. In line with the findings of previous studies reported in the literature related to N-doping of other carbonaceous materials [13,37,45,46], the results obtained from XPS survey spectral analysis (Fig. 1e and S1) and elemental analysis (EA) confirmed the successful insertion of N atoms into the GONR matrix. The EA results (Table S1) showed an increase in N mass concentration from 1.0 to 3.6 % after doping, while an approximate quantification by XPS pointed to an increase in N mass concentration from 0.6 to 3.9 wt% (c.f. Table S2). Despite the sulfur atoms distributed in the carbon material being expected to have catalytic activity for ORR [47], according to the EA results, the sulfur content is very low in GONR with ca. 0.34 wt% and is practically removed after the N-doping process (ca. 0.04 wt% for N-GONR), ruling out a major role of sulfur in the ORR activity and selectivity for the catalytic materials investigated in this study. Apart from the type of precursor used and the quantities and conditions of the synthesis, the degree of nitrogen enrichment after the doping process also depends on the type of carbon matrix employed [37]. N-doped GONR presented relatively higher atomic percentages of 3.4 at.% nitrogen compared to other types of carbonaceous materials previously reported in literature and which were treated in the same way [37]. As the N-doping process entails chemical procedures which involve the use of reducing agents, an obvious decrease in O-content of ∼40 % by EA and 60 % by XPS is observed for the N-GONR in comparison with the undoped GONR (c.f. Tables S1 and S2). The XPS peak deconvolution related to the O 1s region for both samples (Fig. 1f-g, S2, and Table S3) suggests that the amount of carbon bound singly to oxygen (peak at 532.8 eV) corresponding to phenolic, alcohol, or ether groups [48–51] (dominant species in the undoped GONR) decreased drastically after doping GONR with N. The peak deconvolution for the N 1s region (c.f. Fig. 1h, S3, and Table S3) shows that the N-doping process enriched the GONR matrix mainly with pyrrolic (399.8 eV) and pyridinic-N (398.5 eV) groups [13,52,53]. The increase in relative concentration of pyrrolic and pyridinic N species from 37.7 to 66.5 % (c.f. Table S3) and the slight changes from the intensity of the G and G' bands observed in the Raman spectra (Fig. 1i) suggest that the doping of GONR with N leads to the insertion of N-atoms mainly at the GONR edge and defect sites [54]. In addition, the ratio of D and G peak intensities (ID/IG) obtained was 1.48 for the undoped GONR and 1.60 for the N-GONR. The difference observed in the ID/IG ratio points to a slight increase in disorder and the generation of defect sites on the GONR after the doping process [37]. In addition, the small difference in peak intensity at ∼2700 cm−1 is typically attributed to the G’ band and suggests a slightly higher metallicity for the N-doped GONR [55]. The presence of pyrrolic and pyridinic N-groups in the carbon matrix is expected to improve ORR activity via the 4-electron pathway [8,56,57], while the oxygenated groups like carboxylic acid, epoxy, and quinones are expected to act as active sites for ORR via a 2-electron pathway [14,17]. To further investigate the identity of functional groups on the surface, the characteristic vibrations were monitored by FT-IR spectroscopy. Despite presenting overlapping spectral features for different oxygenated functional groups (α, β, and γ–regions) [58,59], the FT-IR spectra results (Fig. 1j) indicate the presence of stretching vibration bands which are typically related to alcoholic groups (around 3100 to ∼3700 cm−1), COOH and CO (∼1700 cm−1), and epoxides (∼1350 cm−1) for both the undoped GONR and N-doped GONR samples [58,59]. Based on the deconvoluted XPS spectra (c.f. Table S3), the band intensities suggest a decrease in epoxide and carboxyl groups after nitrogen doping of GONR. No drastic changes were observed in terms of N-groups for both, the undoped GONR and N-GONR; this was probably due to the low atomic content of N. Nonetheless, the band around 1500 to 1600 cm−1, which corresponds to the CC, CO, and CN stretching vibration [58–61], was found to be slightly more intense for N-GONR than for the undoped GONR. Furthermore, the elongated band observed around 3100 to ∼3700 cm−1, which typically corresponds to the overlap of C-OH, COOH, H2O, and NH stretching bands [58–60,62], indicated an additional insertion of amino groups into the GONR matrix. In general, these results show that, despite exhibiting differences in atomic contents of O and N (and slight differences in O- and N-functional groups), the N-GONR presented physicochemical characteristics similar to the undoped GONR. 3.2 ORR activity and selectivity We examined ORR activity and selectivity for the undoped and N-doped GONR samples in both HClO4 0.1 M and KOH 0.1 M electrolyte solutions. LSV curves were recorded in O2-saturated solutions using a RRDE setup, as shown in Fig. 2 . For the acidic electrolyte, Fig. 2a-c shows that the incorporation of N groups and the depletion of O groups on the GONR surface after doping with nitrogen impacted the ORR activity and selectivity. The LSV curves for the disk electrode (Fig. 2a) exhibited an increase of ∼200 mV in the half-wave potential (E 1/2) and a hike in the diffusion-limited current density (j d) from 2.3 to 2.8 mA cm−2 for ORR, while the LSV curves for the ring electrode (Fig. 2b) presented a decrease in ring currents (from 150 to ∼100 µA) after doping the GONR with N; these changes led to the enhancement of the electrocatalytic activity, favoring the production of water. The potential dependent selectivity toward H2O2 ( S H 2 O 2 , in percentage) was calculated based on the disk and ring data; this can be found in Fig. 2c. When doped with nitrogen, the selectivity toward H2O2 decreases from 83 % to 53 %. Although this has not been well clarified in the literature, the N and O groups are responsible for regulating the formation of H2O or H2O2 as major ORR product [7,15,63–65]. The improved catalytic activity exhibited by the N-GONR (displacement of E 1/2 to more positive values) can be attributed to the enrichment of the GONR matrix with N groups (mainly pyrrolic and pyridinic groups) after doping the sample (c.f. Fig. 2 and Table S3). Previous studies have shown that the pyrrolic and pyridinic groups in nitrogen-doped carbon materials enhance the catalytic activity and selectivity toward the production of water [7,63,66]. Similar to the results obtained under the acidic medium, the analysis in alkaline medium also led to the enhancement of ORR activity and an increased selectivity toward the production of water after doping GONR with N (Fig. 2d-f). As shown in Fig. 2d, the onset ORR potential (E onset) shifts from 0.78 to 0.89 VRHE after doping GONR with N. An increase in cathodic disk current densities concomitantly with a decrease in ring currents from 136 to ∼110 µA led to a diminished selectivity toward HO2 − from 56 % to 38 % after doping GONR with N. ORR activity and selectivity toward H2O were found to improve markedly by the incorporation of higher amount of nitrogen moieties, specifically pyridinic and pyrrolic-N groups, under the application of the two electrolytes evaluated in this study. Furthermore, the lower oxygen content observed after doping GONR with N is found to influence the mechanism by which the ORR preferentially occurs. These observations are in accordance with other results previously reported in the literature involving N-doping of different carbonaceous matrices in both acidic and alkaline media [13,37,51]. 3.3 Electrochemical analysis after the application of oxidative potentials Surface changes may eventually occur due to the application of high potentials above 1.4 VRHE mainly during the start-stop processes in fuel cells [19–21]. Strongly oxidative potentials (>1.2 VRHE) have been reported to be sufficiently high to lead to significant surface changes in carbon-based materials, which may in turn cause changes in the catalytic ORR performance [67–69]. In order to correlate the oxidative stress with the ORR performance, we deliberately subjected the N-doped and undoped GONR catalysts to the following varying oxidative potentials: 1.5, 1.7, and 1.9 VRHE under chronoamperometric analysis; this was done in order to investigate possible changes in both acidic and alkaline media. The results obtained from the analysis of the influence of different potentials on ORR activity and selectivity can be found in Fig. 3 and S5. The surface changes were monitored by CV, XPS, FTIR, Raman, and TEM; this can be viewed in the next section. 3.3.1 0.1 M HClO4 solution In acidic medium, the changes observed in the LSV curves for the N-doped GONR (Fig. 3) point to drastic alterations in ORR activity and selectivity promoted by the exposure of the catalyst to oxidative potentials. As the N-doped GONR surface is exposed to higher potentials, the ORR activity decreases as the LSV curves shift toward lower potentials while the selectivity toward H2O2 increases. Intriguingly, Fig S5 shows that the GONR surface suffered only slight changes after exposure to oxidative potentials since the LSV curves exhibited small deviations after the chronoamperometry measurements at 1.9 VRHE for 30 min; this outcome points to high electrochemical stability of the catalyst in acidic medium. For a better comparison, Fig. 4 a correlates the average selectivity for H2O2 under the applied potential for both the N-GONR and the undoped GONR. As can be observed, the selectivity of the GONR toward H2O2 production remains constant (∼82 %) even after the application of different highly oxidative potentials (1.5 VRHE, 1.7 VRHE and 1.9 VRHE). Conversely, the selectivity of the N-doped GONR toward H2O2 production increases from 56 % to 82 % after the application of 1.9 VRHE; this result shows that the N-doped catalyst exhibits ORR electrocatalytic behavior similar to the undoped catalyst (c.f. Fig. 3). In acidic medium and upon the exposure of the N-doped GONR to increasingly high oxidative potentials, the catalyst is found to exhibit a pattern of behavior that is similar to the undoped GONR in terms of activity and selectivity. In order to investigate the changes on the surface of the catalysts, cyclic voltammograms were recorded after exposure of the undoped GONR and N-doped GONR to highly oxidative potentials; the results obtained are presented in Fig. 4b. After the application of chronoamperometry at 1.9 VRHE for 30 min, the quinone/hydroquinone redox couple (Q/H) for the treated N-GONR increases in comparison to the untreated N-GONR. Thus, it is clear that the voltammetric profile of N-GONR converges to the CV response of the undoped GONR after the application of chronoamperometry at 1.9 VRHE for 30 min. On both the N-GONR and undoped GONR surfaces, one notices that the quinone formation peaks shift to higher potentials while the quinone reduction peak shifts to lower potentials after the exposure to oxidative stress. This observed shift in Q/H ratio has previously been pointed and used as an indication of the degradation of carbon support resulting from electrochemical oxidation [70]. In our case, the catalytically more active and more selective (toward H2O production) N-GONR was found to present the same electrocatalytic behavior as the undoped GONR after electrochemical oxidation. To further evaluate the electrochemical stability of the undoped GONR and N-GONR, we monitored carbon oxidation during chronoamperometric measurements using on-line DEMS. During the DEMS experiments, the ionic current signal of CO2 (m/z = 44) was used as an indicator of carbon corrosion [71,72]; the results obtained from this analysis are shown in Fig. 5 (and Fig. S6). As can be noted, both the undoped GONR and N-GONR exhibited a very similar pattern of carbon loss which became more intense when potentials above 1.7 VRHE were applied. However, the intensity of the CO2 signal detected for the N-GONR was ca. 2 times less intense compared to that of the undoped GONR. The carbon corrosion behavior of the undoped GONR and N-GONR was compared with that of Vulcan carbon - a carbonaceous reference material that has a relatively low graphitization degree. Interestingly, the undoped GONR and N-GONR (especially the N-GONR) were found to experience less significant carbon oxidation compared to Vulcan carbon. In contrast to N-GONR, Vulcan carbon exhibited sharp CO2 signals which became more intense as the applied potential was increased from 1.5 to 1.9 VRHE; the intensity of the CO2 signal in Vulcan carbon was found to diminish over time, indicating the occurrence of efficient surface passivation which mitigated carbon corrosion [71]. Fig. 5 also shows the ionic current signal for O2 (m/z = 32) used for monitoring the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) during the chronoamperometric assays. Here, oxygen evolution was not detected when the potentials ranging from 1.5 to 1.9 VRHE were applied in acidic medium. In acidic medium, carbon corrosion was found to be less intense for the N-GONR compared to the undoped GONR while Vulcan carbon exhibited the highest corrosion. However, even though the N-GONR exhibited the lowest carbon corrosion, the surface changes derived from the exposure of the catalyst to oxidative potentials were still sufficient to cause substantial effects on ORR activity and selectivity. On the other hand, the undoped GONR, which exhibited relatively high corrosion compared to the N-GONR, recorded no changes in its ORR catalytic activity and selectivity. 3.3.2 0.1 M KOH solution In alkaline medium, the N-GONR (Fig. 3d-f) shows moderate changes in ORR activity and selectivity after exposure to oxidative potentials, where it exhibits a pattern of behavior similar to that observed in acidic medium. When the N-GONR is exposed to high oxidative potentials, the catalyst exhibits a decrease in ORR activity and a slight increase in selectivity toward H2O2 production. Furthermore, the diffusion-limited current densities of the N-GONR decrease from −3.6 to −3.2 mA cm−2 while the ring currents vary slightly under higher chronoamperometric potentials; this outcome can be attributed to the instability of the catalyst film when subjected to high potentials in alkaline media. For comparison purposes, the changes observed in the disk and ring LSV curves shown in Fig. S5 demonstrate that the electrocatalytic surface of the undoped GONR undergoes drastic changes after its exposure to oxidative potentials. The diffusion-limited current density of the disk electrode decreases from −3.6 to −2.0 mA cm−2, while the maximum ring current decreases from 135 to 107 µA after applying the potential of 1.5 VRHE for 30 min. Thus, the selectivity (toward H2O2 production) of N-GONR changes from 38 to 49 % after the application of different oxidative potentials, while the selectivity of the undoped GONR increases from 56 % to 81 % after applying the potential of 1.5 VRHE for 30 min (Fig. 4c). Furthermore, the CVs obtained after chronoamperometry at 1.5 VRHE for 30 min (Fig. 4d) showed a significant decrease in capacitive currents for the undoped GONR compared to the N-GONR; this outcome also demonstrates that the surface of the undoped GONR is more affected by the applied potential. Essentially, these results point to higher stability of N-groups in alkaline solution in comparison to acidic solution. In alkaline medium, no DEMS measurements were performed as the ionic current signal of CO2 (m/z = 44) may lead to misleading results due to possible conversion into carbonate (2OH– + CO2 → CO3 2– + H2O) [71,72]. 3.4 Investigating surface changes in catalyst samples after applying oxidative potentials To investigate the effects of applying different potentials on the N-GONR and undoped GONR surfaces in both acidic and alkaline media, an analysis was performed using XPS, FT-IR, Raman, and TEM techniques. The results obtained from these analyses are shown in Figs. 6-8 (as well as in S2-4 and S7). With regard to the chronoamperometric tests carried out in acidic electrolyte, Fig. 6a shows that the atomic ratio between O and C (estimated by XPS; c.f. Fig S1) for the N-GONR sample increases from 0.05 to 0.10, evidencing the high degree of oxidation derived from the application of chronoamperometry at 1.9 VRHE for 30 min. On the other hand, the atomic ratio between N and C for the N-GONR decreases slightly from 0.04 to 0.03; this outcome points to a possible removal of nitrogenous groups through oxidation after applying the potential of 1.9 VRHE for 30 min. The peak deconvolution of the XPS spectra in the C 1s region (Fig. 6b and Table S3) for the N-GONR reveals that the O-content related to CO (at ∼286 eV, of phenolic, alcohol, and/or ether), CO (287.5 eV), and COOH (∼289 eV) groups [13,48–51] increases from 18 to 22 % after chronoamperometry at the potential of 1.9 VRHE for 30 min. Furthermore, the increase of approximately 1 % observed in CCH (at ∼285 eV, of aliphatic) bonds [13,48–51] points to a slight increase in the number of defects in the carbon matrix after chronoamperometry [49]. The peak deconvolution of the spectra in the N 1s region (Fig. 6c, S3 and Table S3) shows that the oxidized-N content increases from 10.1 to 15.4 % after oxidation, while the content of pyrrolic groups decreases from 50.8 to 47.9 %; this outcome shows that the additional N-oxidized groups formed were mostly derived from the oxidation of pyrrolic groups after the exposure to oxidative potential. On the other hand, the atomic O/C ratio for the undoped GONR (Fig. 6a) did not undergo any significant alteration after the application of the same oxidative potential (applied for the N-doped GONR). The N/C atomic ratio for the undoped GONR remained practically unchanged (<0.01) after the application of oxidative potential. However, the peak deconvolution in the C 1s region (Fig. S4 and Table S3) related to the undoped GONR showed an increase of ca. 2.5 % in CCH bonds; this outcome points to a slight increase in the number of defects in the carbon matrix after chronoamperometry. The XPS spectra in the N 1s region are shown in Fig. 6c, S3 and Table S3. For the undoped GONR, the oxidized-N content increases from 11.3 to 20.3 % after chronoamperometry at 1.9 VRHE for 30 min, while the graphitic-N content decreases from 51.1 to 33.7 %. For the N-GONR, the drastic decrease in ORR activity and increase in selectivity toward H2O2 production after oxidative stress can be attributed to the following: 1) oxidation of pyrrolic-N groups and a general decrease in nitrogen moieties as these groups favor the formation of water as final product; and 2) the enrichment of CO functional groups (hydroxyl and ether groups), CO bonds (c.f. Table S4) related to quinone groups, and COOH groups which are regarded as electrocatalytically active surface sites that favor the 2-electron ORR pathway [13,44,73–75]. These results demonstrate that altering the oxygen and nitrogen ratios by exposing carbon catalysts to high potentials enables to tailor the ORR activity and selectivity. In alkaline medium, the O/C atomic ratio for the N-GONR increases from 0.05 to 0.10 (same variation observed in acidic medium), while the O/C atomic ratio for the undoped GONR changes from 0.14 to 0.17 after the application of chronoamperometry at 1.5 VRHE for 30 min (Fig. 6a). The deconvolution of the C 1s and O 1s regions for the N-GONR shown in Fig. 6b, S2 and Table S3 points to an increase from 18 to 24 % in O-content related to CO (for phenolic, alcohol, and/or ether structures) CO, and COOH groups. In addition, the amount of CCH bonds increases from 23 to 28 %, indicating the development of new defects in the carbon matrix after chronoamperometry. For the undoped GONR, the amount of CO, CO, and COOH groups decreases from 28.2 to 18.8 % in the C 1s region (Fig. S4), while in the O 1s region, the amount of CO and COOH groups increases from 2.4 to 17.7 % after the application of chronoamperometry in alkaline medium (Fig. S2). For both the N-GONR and undoped GONR, there was no clear deconvolution of the π– π * transition in the C1s spectrum; this shows that both surfaces are less graphitic after oxidation [76]. With regard to the N-content, the N/C atomic ratio for the N-GONR decreases slightly from 0.04 to 0.03 after being subjected to oxidative stress. For the undoped GONR, the N/C atomic ratio decreases slightly from 0.006 to 0.0005 after the exposure of the catalyst to oxidative potential; this result is very similar to that obtained in acidic medium. The deconvolution peaks related to the N 1s region (c.f. Fig. 6c, S3 and Table S3) for the N-GONR show that the oxidized-N content increases from 10.1 to 22.4 % after the catalyst is subjected to oxidative potential, while the content of pyrrolic groups decreases from 50.8 to 38.6 %. For the undoped GONR, the oxidized-N content increases from 11.3 to 27.8 %, while the main depletion is found to be associated with the graphitic-N content which decreases from 51.1 to 17.7 %. The additional N-oxidized groups formed in the N-GONR during electrochemical oxidation were mostly derived from the oxidation of pyrrolic-N groups. For the undoped GONR, the additional N-oxidized groups were derived from the oxidation of graphitic-N groups; thus, a decrease in pyrrolic-N and graphitic-N groups at the same time with the increase in the relative content of CO, CO and COOH groups (c.f. Fig. 6, S3-S5 and Table S4) are found to favor the formation of HO2 − as the final product of ORR. These results are well in line with the electrochemical observations previously discussed in this paper. The results obtained from the FT-IR spectroscopy analysis presented in Fig. 7a,b provide further evidence for the changes that occurred in the functional groups on the surfaces of both the N-GONR and the undoped GONR catalyst samples. Clearly, one can detect substantial changes in the three regions related to the overlapping of the vibrational modes for different oxygenated functional groups in both the N-GONR and the undoped GONR [58,59]. The changes can be found to be more evident in the γ-region (in the range of 1280–1500 cm−1) which corresponds to the vibrational modes of oxygenated groups such as ether, epoxides, and carboxyl. The peak intensities can be found to increase after the application of chronoamperometry in both acidic and alkaline media; this outcome points to an increase in the production of oxygenated functional groups [58,59]. The peak intensities at 660 and 800 cm−1 are found to increase after oxidation; these peak intensities are associated with bending out-of-plane vibration for hydroxyl groups and stretching vibration for edge ether termination, respectively [58,59]. The increase in peak intensity related to the edge ether termination has also been observed for carbon materials after being subjected to chemical oxidation and thermal treatment, and its occurrence has been pointed out when other oxygen functional groups are removed from carbon matrices [58,59]. The Raman spectra for the N-GONR and the undoped GONR prior to and after chronoamperometric measurements are shown in Fig. 7c,d. All the samples can be found to exhibit two first order peaks which are typical of graphene-based materials: one at ∼1329 cm−1, which can be related to d-band and corresponds to the presence of disordered amorphous carbon (also regarded as an indicator of defective edges), and a less intense second peak at ∼1585 cm−1 that corresponds to G-band and which represents tangential vibrations of graphitic carbon atom [51,55,77,78]. In general, slight changes are observed after the doping of GONR with nitrogen before and after electrochemical oxidation. After the application of chronoamperometry, the ID/IG ratio for the N-GONR increases from 1.60 to 1.94 and the undoped GONR exhibits an increase in ID/IG ratio from 1.48 to 1.71 – this result can primarily be attributed to a decrease in intensity of the G-band in both acidic and alkaline media. The increase in the ID/IG ratios can be interpreted as an increase in disorder and in the generation of new defects in both the N-GONR and the undoped GONR [37]; this outcome is in good agreement with the XPS data. Furthermore, these results show that the ordered graphitic carbon domains corrode irreversibly during chronoamperometry, making the surface of graphene nanoribbons increasingly disordered [25]. To gain a better understanding of the structural and morphological changes that occurred in the catalysts after electrochemical treatment, TEM imaging analysis was used to evaluate the samples prior to and after chronoamperometry - see Fig. 8 and S7. After 30 min of chronoamperometry at 1.9 VRHE in acidic electrolyte, the nanoribbons for both the N-GONR and undoped GONR samples presented no observable surface changes. However, after 30 min of chronoamperometry at 1.5 VRHE in alkaline solution, the graphene nanoribbons of the undoped GONR sample suffered significant surface damages [79], especially on the edges - which became more irregular. For the N-GONR, the damage at the nanoribbon edges was found to be less severe, and this outcome is in good agreement with our electrochemical and spectroscopic results. 3.5 Overall comparisons and trends Overall, the doping of the catalyst with nitrogen, mainly pyrrolic and pyridinic-N groups, leads to the improvement in ORR activity, favoring the 4-electron pathway in both acidic and alkaline media; unlike the N-doped GONR, the undoped GONR is more selective toward ORR via the 2-electron pathway. After subjecting the Vulcan, N-GONR, and undoped GONR to high potentials, we were able to draw the following conclusions: 1) Vulcan carbon and undoped GONR are easily oxidized when oxidative potentials are applied, which means that N-doping increases the electrochemical stability by the mitigation of carbon losses. 2) In terms of impacts on catalytic performance for ORR, the N-GONR is catalytically more active and more selective toward the reduction of O2 to H2O and tends to present the same electrocatalytic behavior as the undoped GONR when exposed to oxidative potentials. After electrochemical treatment at high anodic potentials, the N-GONR becomes catalytically less active for ORR while H2O2 is produced more effectively in both acidic and alkaline media. 3) The decrease in ORR activity and the concomitant increase in H2O2 production after the exposure of N-GONR to oxidative potential (in comparison with the undoped GONR) can be attributed to the following: i) the oxidation of N groups and a general decrease in N-content (the presence of these groups tends to favor the formation of water as the final product of ORR); and ii) the increase in the content of functional groups: CO (of hydroxyl and ether groups), CO (related to quinone groups), and COOH which are regarded as electrocatalytically active surface sites that favor the 2-electron ORR pathway. Together, these outcomings demonstrate that N-doping/O-doping increases the stability of earth abundant carbon materials to resist oxidative potentials alongside the alteration of ORR activity and selectivity (Fig. S8). 4 Conclusion In summary, we have shown how nitrogen insertion into GONR (O-doped carbon catalyst) improves the ORR activity for N-GONR, favoring the 4-electron pathway, while O-doping favors the 2-electron pathway towards H2O2. Regarding the stability against electrochemical oxidation, the carbon loss takes place at lower rates for the N-doped carbon catalyst in comparison to the O-doped carbon and Vulcan carbon. When N-GONR becomes exposed to oxidative potentials, H2O2 is produced more effectively exhibiting the same electrocatalytic behavior as the O-doped carbon. The increase in H2O2 formation is attributed to the following factors: i) the oxidation of N groups and nitrogen loss; and ii) the increase in the relative content of CO, CO, and COOH functional groups. These outcomes indicate that the N-doping leads to enhanced stabilization against corrosion and higher H2O2 selectivities. Our findings are of great interest for the design of improved metal-free carbon-based catalysts that are capable of maintaining their activity and selectivity for a long time. coredata.dc:description: Carbon materials have widespread use in catalysis mainly due to their abundance, high conductivity, large surface area, and facile functionalization through heteroatom-doping. However, both, the stability against corrosion and the catalytic performance caused by the exposure to high potentials present in relevant electrocatalytic reactions such as the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is recurrently underestimated. We demonstrate that importance of oxygen and nitrogen binding motives to tailor the oxygen reduction activity, selectivity and stability against corrosion. Spectroscopic results revealed that the exposure to high oxidative potentials causes i) oxidation of N-groups and decrease in N content; and ii) enrichment of CO (hydroxyl and ethers), CO (quinones), and COOH functional groups and, together, dramatically impact the ORR activity and selectivity. We present guidelines how the activity, selectivity and stability can be precisely tuned. The developed guidelines highlight the potential of tailoring the oxygen and nitrogen containing functional groups on carbon catalysts for future catalytic applications.
coredata.dc:title: A comprehensive comparison of oxygen and nitrogen functionalities in carbon and their implications for the oxygen reduction reaction
